skill.name: web-auth
skill.description: Authentication patterns for React web applications. Use when implementing login flows, OAuth, JWT handling, session management, or protected routes in React web apps.
skill.summary: Authentication patterns for React web applications. Use when implementing login flows, OAuth, JWT ha...
skill.author: CJHarmath

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing authentication patterns. No executable code, scripts, or network operations. Pure markdown with TypeScript code examples for legitimate security patterns.

content.value_statement: Building secure login flows and session management in React requires understanding multiple authentication patterns. This skill provides production-ready code examples for JWT, OAuth, cookies, and protected routes.
actual_capabilities: Implement cookie-based authentication with httpOnly cookies
Build OAuth login flows with Google Identity Services
Create protected routes in React Router and Next.js
Handle automatic token refresh and session management
Add CSRF protection and security headers
Set up NextAuth.js with credentials and OAuth providers
limitations: Backend server code is not provided (FastAPI examples are reference only)
No database integration or user storage patterns
No biometric or hardware token integration

output_examples.input: How do I store JWT tokens securely in a React application?
output: Best option: httpOnly cookies - XSS safe, protects tokens from JavaScript access
Alternative: In-memory storage with refresh tokens - highest security for short-lived tokens
Avoid: localStorage - vulnerable to XSS attacks that can steal tokens
Always use credentials: 'include' with fetch to send cookies with requests

best_practices: Use httpOnly, secure cookies instead of localStorage for tokens to prevent XSS theft
Implement automatic token refresh to handle expired sessions gracefully
Add CSRF protection when using cookies with credentials: 'include'
anti_patterns: Storing JWT tokens in localStorage - vulnerable to XSS attacks
Storing sensitive data in browser storage without encryption
Not validating tokens on the server before trusting authenticated requests

faq.question: What is the most secure way to store auth tokens in React?
faq.answer: httpOnly cookies are the most secure. They cannot be accessed by JavaScript, protecting against XSS attacks that could steal tokens.

faq.question: Can this skill help with Next.js authentication?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill includes NextAuth.js configuration examples and middleware patterns for protecting routes in the Next.js App Router.

faq.question: Does this skill include backend authentication code?
faq.answer: Backend code is reference only. The FastAPI examples show how to set cookies and validate tokens but are not complete production implementations.

faq.question: Is the authentication code safe to use as-is?
faq.answer: The patterns follow security best practices. Always audit and test in your specific environment before production use.

faq.question: What OAuth providers are covered?
faq.answer: The skill includes Google OAuth examples and NextAuth.js configuration that supports Google, GitHub, and credentials-based login.

faq.question: How does this compare to other authentication libraries?
faq.answer: This skill teaches core patterns. For production apps, consider NextAuth.js or Auth0 which handle edge cases and security updates automatically.
